intro: Microchilus boyacanus, commonly known as the Boyacá microchilus, is a species of flowering plant native to the Andean region of Colombia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and has small, delicate flowers that bloom in clusters. Its botanical features include finely divided leaves and a compact growth habit, making it well adapted to its mountainous environment. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
